subject: Sleep
title: Japanese Inemuri
description: A micro-lesson that makes Japanese Inemuri usable.

hook.text: In Japan, falling asleep in a meeting signals dedication, not laziness. It means you worked so hard you collapsed.

buildup.text: Inemuri means sleeping while present. It's socially acceptable in workplaces, trains, and even parliament.

discovery.text: The practice reflects a culture where visible exhaustion proves commitment to work and community duties.

twist.text: There are rules. You must remain upright, appear ready to rejoin, and your status must be high enough to allow it.

climax.text: Inemuri masks a serious problem. Japan has some of the shortest sleep durations of any developed nation.

punchline.text: Japan normalized public napping but still hasn't normalized enough private sleep.

quiz.question: What is inemuri?
options: Socially accepted sleeping while present, signaling dedication
